channel.title: IRC bot [updated]
channel.description:
[b]Introduction[/b] So I wrote an IRC bot (now: revision 2) because my previous one was horrible. This one is heavily-commented, sorry if it bothers you. Please provide constructive criticism! Thanks :)
[b]API[/b] Attached.

item.dc:creator: @Aftermath_961 Aftermath
item.description:
@Aftermath_961 wrote:

Yes, but the user shouldn’t have to override your setName/getName method for changing nicknames to work, changing nicks is something expected to be standard which isn’t currently supported in your base class.

item.title: IRC bot [updated]
item.dc:creator: @Rixxx Rix_
item.description:
@Rixxx wrote:

Aftermath:

This really should come with your code rather than the user’s as it’s basic expected functionality.

Changing nicknames is what the user (if any :P) does. The getSomething() methods override the abstract methods in the Bot class.

Aftermath:

It’s interesting that you made the IRC commands into separate objects (in a good way). As per standards though they should be lowercase aside from initial letters. They should probably follow a proper heirarchy e.g. IrcCommand.

I’m assuming you’re talking about the PRIVMSG class, etc. IMO, naming is just personal preference but I’ll do it in the next build.

John459:

Good work with v2, it is much better.

Thanks.

Read full topic

item.title: IRC bot [updated]
item.dc:creator: @John459 John459
item.description:
@John459 wrote:

Good work with v2, it is much better.

Read full topic

item.title: IRC bot [updated]
item.dc:creator: @Aftermath_961 Aftermath
item.description:
@Aftermath_961 wrote:

v2 of Bot looks much better than before, haven’t really checked out anything else.

Regarding the abstract getName() / etc fields, personally I would just have them be concrete in the abstract class and return a variable set to a default. The current methods reminds me of Aryan / RSBot scripts what with the getScriptName / getScriptCategory interface methods which every script had to override. The disadvantage to this is that your class user has to add his own functionality for changing nicknames (e.g. making a set method). This really should come with your code rather than the user’s as it’s basic expected functionality.

It’s interesting that you made the IRC commands into separate objects (in a good way). As per standards though they should be lowercase aside from initial letters. They should probably follow a proper heirarchy e.g. IrcCommand.

Read full topic

item.title: IRC bot [updated]
item.dc:creator: @Rixxx Rix_
item.description:
@Rixxx wrote:

chri5:

snip

Although that would be extra work for whoever wants to make a new bot out of it, it’s a good idea. However, I believe I would need to include [tt]IrcBot[/tt] as a param to the [tt]IrcEventListener[/tt] constructor (because looking at the code now, I don’t know how you can access the IrcBot class from the MyIrcEventListener subclass).

Lothy:

snip snip

I don’t like the idea of mapping lines from the server into HashMap before it is parsed. I’m thinking of separate classes for respective lines sent by the server and handling it something like this (pseudo-code):

onMessage(new PRIVMSG(channel, message, someone));

[quote=“Davidi2, post:15, topic:369327”]I know they are overwritten, but my point is that they are pointless. Unless you have a variable that you need to get, returning a “” string is, to put it lightly, rather stupid. And if someone edits the nick of the bot, it will still return the same thing. Which is why it is easier to do something like set the nick/channel of the bot in the bots constructor, then just use that to set some variables.
…the fuck? I suggest making a new thread for it because you’re using a while loop…[/quote]
…that was the point of overriding the getSomething() methods. I’m guessing that you are suggesting that I instantiate a Bot in the subclass, right?

[quote=“Davidi2, post:15, topic:369327”][quote author=chri5 link=topic=465462.msg3404376#msg3404376 date=1290211117]
Edit: Infact, “the whole point of an interface like this”. Please stick to moparscape.
[/quote]http://mindprod.com/jgloss/interfacevsabstract.html
Nothing I was talking about was specific to interfaces or abstract classes. Go away[/quote]
Also, if you actually read my code, there isn’t any interface. It’s an abstract class.

The reason why tt[/tt] is there because some idiot might edit the nickname of the bot but forget to change it as well in the check. You also seem to contradict yourself about suggesting me to make a thread for the input reader, because clearly the problem, of using [tt]BufferedReader[/tt] and [tt]BufferedWriter[/tt] in the Bot class only one time, remains.[/quote]I know they are overwritten, but my point is that they are pointless. Unless you have a variable that you need to get, returning a “” string is, to put it lightly, rather stupid. And if someone edits the nick of the bot, it will still return the same thing. Which is why it is easier to do something like set the nick/channel of the bot in the bots constructor, then just use that to set some variables.
…the fuck? I suggest making a new thread for it because you’re using a while loop…

item.title: IRC bot [updated]
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“chri5, post:9, topic:369327”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=465462.msg3404324#msg3404324 date=1290208713]

[quote author=Unhandled link=topic=465462.msg3404082#msg3404082 date=1290199283]

Also abusing the this keyword in connect()

protip: being explicit is not the same as abuse.
[/quote]un-needed code is un-needed

ITT: Davidi not knowing the difference between abstract and interface.
[/quote]the fuck?

ITT: chri5 not knowing what I’m talking about

Nothing I said had to do with the difference between abstract and interface classes

Besides using the ‘this’ keyword excessively (which is just an opinion, I guess), everything I said was correct?

I’m just saying that his getters are pointless because they return a direct string, not a variable.

nice job editing your post faggot

Edit: Infact, “the whole point of an interface like this”. Please stick to moparscape.[/quote]
How is someone supposed to get better if you try to send them to moparscape? :rolleyes:

Anyway, regarding what has been said by him so far:

  1. Using this/super is obviously optional. I always use the this keyword in constructors, mutator methods (setters), and overridden versions of equals(Object). Unnecessary, but ultimately just a matter of style. I use super in constructors too. As long as it remains consistent, it’s fine.
  2. Given that his code is quite readable, commenting on style adds no value to the discussion.

As far as usable feedback goes on my part, I offer this:
You should have designed your bot in such a way that it was extensible, because adding extra functionality in its current state is going to be a nightmare.

What you really need is an input handler interface of some sort, and then you can implement a concrete input handler for each type of expected input. You would then map a String (such as PRIVMSG) to an InputHandler, and when that type of message arrives you would delegate the handling of the message to the appropriate InputHandler.

You could then reuse such an interface to handle commands too, by having the PRIVMSG InputHandler have its own collection of InputHandler classes, each designed to handle a single command.

Check the Java 6 API for java.util.Map and java.util.HashMap.

As for the interface, you could use:
public interface InputHandler {
void handle(String[] inputArgs);
}

Obviously inputArgs would be the string of text that the bot received from the server, split up into parts using an appropriate regex. By passing it to the handler in that form, you avoid extra operations on the input before delegating it to the handler.

Read full topic

item.title: IRC bot [updated]
item.dc:creator: @chri5 chri5
item.description:
@chri5 wrote:

Rixxx:

chri5, really, it’s hard to imagine what you’re trying to suggest without any pseudo-code.

Like this. Sorry it’s not too in depth, but it should give you an idea of what I meant.

[code=java]public class IrcBot
{
private IrcEventListener eventListener;

public IrcBot(String server, String nickname)
{
	//connect
}


//other methods

public void setNickname(String nickname)
{
	//update the nickname here
}

public void joinChannel(String channelName)
{
	//join the channel
}

public void setEventListener(IrcEventListener eventListener)
{
	this.eventListener = eventListener;
}

}[/code]

[code=java]public class IrcEventListener
{
public void onMessage(String channel, String message, String nickname)
{
//
}

public void onJoin(String channel, String nickname)
{
	//empty so the user doesn't have to end up having a massive class!
}

//other methods

}[/code]

Example:

public class IrcBotTest { public static void main(String[] argv) { IrcBot bot = new IrcBot("irc.strictfp.com", "chris"); bot.setEventListener(new MyIrcEventListener()); bot.joinChannel("#chat"); bot.joinChannel("#code"); } }

public class MyIrcEventListener extends IrcEventListener { public void onJoin(String channel, String nickname) { System.out.println(nickname + " has joined " + channel); } }

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @chri5 chri5
item.description:
@chri5 wrote:

ITT: Davidi not knowing the difference between abstract and interface.

Must admit I’d preferred a class (something like IrcBot) with methods such as setNick and joinChannel etc, and a separate abstract class for event listeners. If this was updated to be good I’d use this as I cannot be arsed making my own, and the majority of projects which do exist are terrible.

Read full topic

item.title: IRC bot [updated]
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[code=java] @Override
public String getNick() {
return “JoinBot”;
}

    @Override
    public String getUser() {
            return "JoinBot";
    }

    @Override
    public String getChannel() {
            return "#joinbot";
    }[/code]

lol’d

The only point of getters and setters is for external classes to read/set a variable.

.equals(getNick())
is the same as
.equals(“JoinBot”);

Something where you set the nicks username, nick, and channel upon instantiation, in the constructor, and then setting some variables for them would be much better:

Also, the whole point of an interface like this is that you are not calling each separate instance of it by itself. Something like a main class that calls the JoinBot class and starts it would be much better.

EDIT -
Also, output class has a bot variable, which is never use?
Also abusing the this keyword in connect()
Also, you are creating the bufferedReader and writer variables in Bot class, but then you immediately put them into the Input & Output classes, and never use them again.
Also, you might want a new thread for your input reader
Also: while ((line = bufferedReader.readLine()) != null) { } if (line == null) running = false;lol’d

Read full topic
